results.title: Permutations
results.brief_description:
An early example of computer generated animation; several hundred dots move about the screen according to a set of
instructions in a graphics program which were input into a
IBM digital computer and coloured by an optical printer.
‘Action sequences, proceeding from order to disorder and back to ordered patterning, suggest a parallel to harmonic phenomena of the musical scale … The effect is to subtly generate and resolve tension - which is similar to the primary emotional power of music composition’ (John Whitney).

results.title: On perspective and motion
results.brief_description: “Using the signature gridwork of alleyways of Melbourne city as a device to explore alternative representations of scale and space, this time-lapse portrait of Melbourne explores the traffic flows; human, vehicular and meterological. One of the main aims of my artistic research is to explore new ways of perceiving the world we inhabit. By using machines to work outside of ‘realtime’ I hope to expose new modes of perception and uncover new forms of spatio/temporal representation. To this end I have developed systems for the control and manipulation of both spatial and temporal ‘camera’ positioning. Accurate and repeatable motion control combined with non linear frame capture and sophisticated digital post production provide the freedom to explore alternative visual representations of space/time, isolating and exaggerating the interwoven physical variables that construct perspective and motion.” Daniel Crooks, 2004

results.title: Drift
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and black and white, silent
results.brief_description: Since the first Apollo moon landing in the 1960s, NASA has compiled an enormous photographic record of its lunar saga. San Francisco photographer Michael Light gained access to the original negatives, presenting his collection of photography in major American and European museums including San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. As a reprise to his photographic exhibition ‘Full Moon’, Light has created ‘Drift’, an epic seven-minute loop of composite still imagery taken during NASA’s moon missions.

results.title: Brother
results.brief_description: The childhood memory of a brother, his cigarette butts, asthma and head lice. An exploration of the simple truths and ironies that make up a life. An iconic Australian film.

results.title: Cousin
results.brief_description: The childhood remembrance of a cousin, his special arm, pet rocks and shopping trolley. He was born with cerebral palsy. The narrator tells of their antics together as children: their attempts to fly off the chook shed roof, out of control shopping trolley rides as well as being introduced to his many assorted collections of tee shirts, pet rocks and toenails.

results.title: The Journey
results.brief_description: An old man sits in a rowboat on an endless gravel ocean remembering episodes from his youth and middle age. The three vignettes presented in this film using model animation come to represent the old man’s search for spiritual meaning and purpose in his life. The tightrope becomes a metaphor for his precarious passage from boyhood to adulthood, while the door and ladder sequence comes to represent the man’s desire for meaning through material wealth. The final rowboat episode thus becomes the pinnacle of the man’s quest - a final search for fulfilment that will take him beyond life.

results.title: Under the weather
results.brief_description: In this whirlwind of stop motion animation, everday domestic objects are whipped into movement by a runaway weather report. A mixture of object animation and live action.

results.title: Serving suggestion
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Kate Riedl and Tony Thorne
results.brief_description: A snot nosed kid called Kevin eats his way through the snack aisle in the supermarket. When Kevin decides to go for the ‘Chocky Pops’, he doesn’t realise that he’ll end up with more than a mouthful. The supermarket becomes a jungle in this impressive computer animated short.

results.title: Pleasure domes
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and Maggie Fooke
results.brief_description: Is Cannes really like St. Kilda, or is it just a state of mind? Animated watercolour drawings and hand coloured photocopies shape this introspective reflection on the nature of landscape and human responses to it. It hints that our perception of landscape is never direct but always filtered through a set of constructs, either physical or psychological.
